entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing User Experience in SAP Guided Buying
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my latest blog. 

My name is Angeline Gregory, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the UK.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Guided Buying.

SAP Guided Buying can steer users towards more efficient and compliant buying processes.  It is crucial to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into your buying processes to enrich the experience.

The below features in SAP Guided Buying make purchasing decisions smoother and smarter and hence improve cost effectiveness and increases compliance.

Catalog Item Recommendation

The item recommendation feature suggests products and services based on users' past purchases.  It collects purchasing history from your organization and uses artificial intelligence to recommend catalog items that might be of interest based on the individual user. Item recommendations display in a carousel at the top of the home page, in the item details page or as alternatives to non-catalog item.

This feature improves productivity by:

  • Encouraging usage of catalog item when creating a non-catalog request​
  • Reducing effort when searching for items​
  • Reducing distractions when browsing
  • Improving user experience ​

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_ITEM_RECOMMENDATIONS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription 
  • At first SAP Guided Buying will show “Popular Items” based on organization’s most frequent purchases.  AI will learn and start showing “Recommended for you” items / services based on users clicks​.

Guided Buying Usage Report

The usage report in Guided Buying gives administrators insight into user searches, purchases, and overall interaction with SAP Guided Buying. SAP Guided Buying generates this report monthly to provides usage details, such as the number of users who signed in, number of users who added items to their cart, total number of items added to carts, and searches that returned no results.  This report helps answer business questions like which catalog areas to expand and the most popular search items.  By leveraging the insights from the Usage Report, organizations can continuously improve user experience based on data.

This feature improves efficiency by:

  • Highlighting opportunities based on user behavior, search patterns​ and search effectiveness analysis​
  • Aids making catalog improvements and helps bring spend under management​
  • Providing evidence- to make quicker design decisions

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • ​This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription
  • SAP Guided Buying generates reports only after at least 100 unique users have cumulatively clicked “Add to cart” more than 1,000 times.  It must first collect and analyze a significant number of searching and purchasing actions 

​By using these features in guided buying systems, organizations can significantly help shape the way users buy goods or services.

Integrating AI and ML into guided buying isn't just about improving technology; it's about strategically enhancing the procurement process better suited to users' needs, while staying compliant and cost effective.

So, whether you are just starting out or looking to refine your procurement processes, consider how AI and ML can make a significant impact on your organization's guided buying system and watch as your bottom line and operational efficiencies improve.

Take the next steps by having a look at our comprehensive one-pager on AI and ML in SAP Guided Buying.

Thank you for reading my blog!!

entry.title: Kickstart Your SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
All you need to know and where to start

You may have come across articles, presentations, interviews or discussions about SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You heard the term quite often, but you might still be asking:  

  • What exactly is SAP BTP?
  • Why is SAP BTP important?
  • And how do I begin exploring SAP BTP’s potential?
  • How does SAP BTP fit into the clean core strategy?

You’re now at the right place.

Whether you're a decision maker looking to drive IT strategy, an IT professional building solutions, a business user focused on innovation, or part of the academic community exploring cutting-edge technologies, this post is your launchpad into the world of SAP BTP.

Curious where you fit in? Keep reading to discover the tools, learning paths, and support SAP BTP offers for every IT role: from developers and architects to students, educators, and decision makers.

No matter your background or goals, there’s a starting point tailored just for you.

 

What We’ll Cover Here

  1. What Is SAP BTP?
  2. Why SAP BTP Matters
  3. SAP BTP and clean core
  4. Try Before You Buy: Trials & Pricing Models
  5. Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?
  6. SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role
  7. Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates
  8. Start building today!

 

What is SAP BTP?

SAP BTP is an intuitive, modern development and innovation platform for both professional IT and business users. It is a unified platform that brings quickly together everything you need to build any idea or business vision to life, extending, and integrating existing business applications, whether they’re SAP or not.

With self-service data discovery, modeling, planning, and analytics for business users in a governed environment, it provides integration solutions to connect and streamline applications and processes across the entire enterprise, offering pre-built business content like built-in data products, integrations, workflows, app templates, and AI services.

Here’s what’s in the toolbox:

  • App Development & Automation: Rapidly develop applications or automate processes using low-code/no-code tools or opt for professional-code development when advanced customization and control are required
  • Data & Analytics: Turn your data into decisions with built-in analytics and planning tools.
  • Integration: Connect SAP or non-SAP systems like a pro.
  • Artificial Intelligence: Infuse AI into your workflows, apps, and decisions.
  • Platform Foundation: Secure, scalable, and ready for hybrid cloud environments.

Simply put, SAP BTP enables you to innovate and stay relevant by building on established foundations.

 

Why SAP BTP Matters?

Because digital transformation is not just a trend, it’s essential for adaptability and resilience, a.k.a. survival.

With SAP BTP, you can:

  • Automate repetitive tasks and free up time for real work.
  • Connect all of your systems, so they integrate.
  • Build custom apps tailored to your business needs and vision.
  • Use AI to make smarter decisions, faster.
  • Connect and harmonize all your data, eliminating data silos
  • Get mission-critical insights from your data without a background in data science

And the best part? You don’t have to start from scratch.
SAP BTP offers thousands of pre-built content packages, from application or automation templates to integration flows to dashboards to AI services.

 

SAP BTP and clean core

Clean core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing agile, innovative and efficient ERP systems. The principles focus on building resilient business processes and extensions supported by seamless integration, efficient operations, and data quality.

Central to the clean core strategy are Side-by-side extensions, powered by SAP BTP.

Side-by-side extensions allow organizations to enhance their SAP landscapes without directly modifying the core SAP S/4HANA system: instead of embedding custom code within the core, new functionalities, integrations, and custom applications are developed and deployed independently on SAP BTP.

This approach leverages SAP BTP's robust services, including various runtime environments (like Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment), development tools (like SAP Business Application Studio and CAP), and critical integration services (like SAP Integration Suite and SAP Event Mesh). Connectivity is securely handled by tools like the SAP Cloud Connector for on-premise systems and the Destination Service, ensuring seamless data exchange via standard APIs and business events from the core.

 

Try Before You Buy: Free Trials & Flexible Pricing Models
Not ready to commit? No problem

SAP BTP offers a 90-day free trial with access to 30+ services.

You can explore, experiment, and learn at your own pace how to build, deploy, and integrate with a full suite of platform services.

Start here your free trial of SAP Business Technology Platform.

When you're ready to scale, you’ve got options:

  • Free Tier: Build small apps, pay only for what you use.
  • Pay-As-You-Go: Great for dynamic needs and innovation projects.
  • Enterprise Agreement: Predictable pricing for known use cases.

Explore all the possibilities SAP BTP unlocks. We’ve outlined the opportunities below:

 

Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?

Thousands of organizations, from global enterprises to emerging startups, are already leveraging SAP BTP to transform their operations. Let their success inspire you.
They are using SAP BTP to:

  • Automate supply chains
  • Personalize customer experiences
  • Streamline HR processes
  • Build AI-powered finance tools ... and achieve much more.

With over 33,000 customers and 3,200 partners, you'll be in excellent company.

See how SAP BTP customers are achieving a measurable impact across industries and lines of business.

Here’s your go-to list of resources to get rolling, matched to your role:

Note: This table is a starting point. Resource-role mappings are suggestions. Feel free to explore beyond your role based on your needs and interests. Find below what each of the resources has to offer.

  • Start your experience with Guided Missions to bring real life use-cases to life

  • Create an estimate of your services to get a first impression about the usage cost.

  • Development & Automation: Accelerate your projects with approximately 650 pre-built workflows, automations, applications, templates, and actions ready for use with SAP Build
  • Analytics: Jump-start your data insights using pre-built dashboards, stories, and data models specifically designed for SAP BTP's analytics capabilities
  • Information: Explore a rich repository of resources, including APIs, events, CDS views, business objects, interfaces, adapters, process blueprints, and SAP-validated partner use cases.

SAP Community - Connect with fellow SAP BTP users, ask questions and share ideas, get help and help others.

 

Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates

entry.title: Part 2: Agentic AI – Governance, risks and dilemmas
entry.content:
Agentic AI is jet another evolution of Traditional AI, right? It brings more than Generative AI (GenAI), but is also carries out some more risks as well… It’s becoming “smart”, it’s making “decisions” – and IBM told us in 1979 we shouldn’t let computers make “decisions” because computers cannot be “accountable”[1]!

I’ve tried to explain the AI evolution path in my previous article (Agentic AI – AI which finally makes sense?). Now, let’s talk about governance, risks and ethical dilemmas.

We should be aware of it, and we should try to address it – in time…

Let’s start with dilemmas…

Agentic AI can make autonomous decisions and based on this it can execute some complex tasks – also autonomously. This can be useful, yes – for sure this is much more than just GenAI assistants, where we had to make the decision and execute task on our own. Now we can have real robotic personal assistants, or self-driving cars, or robotic support agents. Tomorrow (and this tomorrow can come very fast) we will have fully autonomous HR agents and procurement officers, as well as fully autonomous industrial and humanoid robots, and let’s say this loudly – war robots as well (oh, I am sure bunch of people are already working on it, as we speak).

Figure 1. Are we concerned?

Dilemma is clear – where does this lead us at the end? Are we, out of our curiosity (or need to simplify our lives?) producing something which can replace us, or worse?

I do not have an answer on this – future is unwritten chapter – we are writing it now.

Agentic AI is reality, and now we should find the best way to use it! But at the same time,  we must create our future in a smart and sustainable way – and I hope we will.

Now, risks…

As per risks with Agentic AI, like with any AI or GenAI, there are some “standard” risks, for sure. But here I see that primary risk, is the risk of misuse by design – and this I link with the above dilemmas… I am not referring only to wrong design (i.e. being bias), I am referring on more serious “intentional” use for the “wrong” cause. What kind of agents and robots do we want to build? How much autonomy do we really want to give to AI? Although there are many articles, there are effectively no binding principles and guidelines. We are still too much intrigued with Agentic AI (or AI in general) – so no boundaries are set.

But it should be! As long as we do not set reasonable (and sustainable) boundaries, we are at (major?) risk.

Figure 2. Key Risks leading to shortcomings

For the “standard” risks, we have all those any GenAI might have – starting with security vulnerabilities like prompt injection and data poisoning, to model hallucinations. With Agentic AI both can lead not just to “ill” recommendations, but to “bad” decisions and “wrong” actions taken.

Additional risk, also starting with GenAI – the more cognitive tasks we pass to AI, the less cognitive tasks we will execute – this may not be good, in the long run. Similar with Agentic AI – the more decisions and actions are done by AI, the more dependent we become – again, this is not good for us, in the long run.

Are we aware of these risks? Well, we should be…

Can we improve “things” with good Governance?

The key aspect of any governance is to, among others, minimize any shortcomings of the new tools, methods, projects etc. How can we do this for Agentic AI?

  • How do we ensure that Agentic AI System has been built in the transparent and explainable way – so we can easily understand its purpose and ability?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI is fair and responsible – that we do see it as non-bias in making decision?
  • How do we build-in accountability within Agentic AI System (even these are “computers”) – in a way humans can accept it (also avoiding misuse by design)?
  • How do we ensure Agentic AI System is safe to operate of – prompt injection and data poisoning has been effectively prevented.

Many questions… But what are the key governing principles we must follow?

First and the most important – there are no strict or imposed principles and guidelines (at least not yet) what is that Agentic AI System (agent or robot) can and cannot do by design. So, if we talk about “formal” misuse of the technology – sorry there are none or close to none (at least formally) limitations. But “informally” yes – there are those “dilemmas” for potential misuse of the AI (by design).

While it looked like we were very far away from the “real” AI (it was just a hype, right?) we did not care too much about putting any “legislation”. However, now things do not look so distant... The closer we come to real technology break-through toward autonomous robotics – thighs are becoming more and more controversial.

So how to build AI, and especially Agentic AI (or some further evolutions) in a responsible manner?

Figure 3. Responsible AI is Human-centric

Let’s call this Responsible AI magic circle of “interaction”:

  • Agentic AI “imposes” certain Risks
  • Risks do “impact” us, Human
  • Human must “build” Governance rules and practices
  • Governance rules and practices are here to “control” Agentic AI

The fact currently there are no “legally” binding rules and principles, does not prevent us to set company or industry standards on our own – let’s call it AI best practice.

If we talk about rules, let’s start thinking – what is that we want to keep for ourselves? What is that we don’t want AI to do? How far are we from some futuristic scenarios and the need to build basic rules of robotics[2]? Maybe we should be ready to “move over” this mountain and embrace the fact “future is happening right now”!

For principles, things are a bit more straight-forward, and previous AI experiences can really help us:

  1. Risk management: identifying, assessing, and mitigating the unique risks posed by both GenAI and autonomous agents. We should try to address all risks; from compliance risks and what and why do we build (to be transparent and explainable, to be fair and responsible, and ensure maximum possible accountability), to security risks (to be safe to operate).
  2. Continuous monitoring and auditing: agents/robots need to be monitored continuously to detect any deviation from intended behavior, any ethical issues, or security breaches. Also, audit trails and logging of agent decisions are vital for accountability, where (ideally) no agents/robots should access, alter and remove any audit trails and logs.
  3. Organizational structure: creating a cross-functional AI governance boards and bodies to create policies but also monitor adaptation of these policies in all Ai initiatives, with special focus on agents/robots.

All this, and more if needed, can be easily translated into any organization dealing with Agentic AI. Each organization will make adaptations on its own, of course – but key is to be aware of risks and shortcomings, as well as all the potential benefits new Agentic AI technology is bringing. If we are aware, and we try addressing it with proper governance – it’s a good start…

So, can we start all this and be open-minded?

Acknowledgment

*) Intro photo BoliviaInteligente on Unsplash

**) This article uses SAP Business Technology Platform Solution Diagrams & Icons as per SAP Terms of Use  governing the use of these SAP Materials (please note, newer version of the Solution Diagrams & Icons, as well as Terms of Use, might be in place after the publication of this article).

More guidelines on Solution Diagrams & Icons can be found in this article by Bertram Ganz.

References

[1] IBM: AI decision-making: Where do businesses draw the line? | IBM

[2] Isac Asimov: Three Laws of Robotics - Wikipedia

entry.title: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: seguridad reforzada, IA aplicada y nuevas alianzas estratégicas
entry.content:
SAP AI Core y modelos propios en BTP Las empresas ya pueden entrenar y desplegar sus propios modelos en SAP AI Core con integración nativa a datos SAP. Esto abre la puerta a IA especializada en cada industria, pero plantea un dilema: ¿cómo equilibrar innovación con compliance? Una aseguradora podría entrenar un modelo para detección de fraudes, pero ¿qué pasa si no logra explicabilidad suficiente? La promesa es grande, el riesgo también.

¿Tu organización está lista para invertir en IA propia o preferís modelos preentrenados de SAP y partners?

🔗 Más información

Nuevo release de SAP Integration Suite La suite incorpora conectores preconfigurados para Salesforce, Workday y ServiceNow, simplificando arquitecturas híbridas. El beneficio es velocidad en despliegues, pero la realidad es que muchas empresas ya tienen middleware paralelo. Un retail puede ver valor en unificar todo en BTP, pero el costo de “migrar lo viejo” nunca es trivial.

¿Vale la pena consolidar integraciones en una sola plataforma o es mejor convivir con múltiples soluciones?

🔗 Más información

DataSphere y federación en tiempo real SAP Datasphere suma capacidades para federar datos en vivo desde Snowflake y BigQuery, sin replicación masiva. Esto cambia el juego: menos ETL, más velocidad. Una minera podría consultar KPIs financieros y de producción en un único dashboard, pero la latencia y la calidad de metadatos pueden ser talón de Aquiles.

¿Creés que el futuro es federar datos en vivo o seguir apostando a replicar en un único repositorio?

🔗 Más información

Joule for Developers: IA gratis hasta 2026 El programa permite a los desarrolladores usar capacidades de IA generativa dentro de SAP Build Code, Build Apps, Process Automation y entornos ABAP sin costo hasta septiembre de 2026. Esto acelera la creación de aplicaciones, automatiza procesos y mejora la productividad, pero también plantea un reto: ¿cómo asegurar que los equipos realmente adopten la herramienta y no quede como “demo eterna”? Imaginemos un equipo de manufactura que genera código para integrarse con sensores IoT en minutos, pero sin estrategia de adopción puede terminar en pilotos aislados sin impacto real.

¿En tu empresa ya están explorando Joule for Developers o aún se percibe como una prueba de laboratorio sin plan de escalamiento?

🔗 Más información

Gestión de identidades con CIS: más allá del SSO SAP Cloud Identity Services ya no es solo un proveedor de inicio de sesión único: hoy permite aplicar MFA (autenticación multifactor), gestionar identidades externas y controlar accesos en entornos híbridos. El beneficio es claro: menos riesgos de seguridad y más trazabilidad. Pero el desafío aparece en la práctica: ¿quién define los roles y quién se hace responsable de revisarlos periódicamente? Una empresa de energía implementó MFA para usuarios críticos, pero descubrió que sin procesos de recertificación, la complejidad administrativa creció exponencialmente.

¿En tu organización la gestión de identidades es una práctica madura con roles y procesos claros, o sigue siendo una tarea reactiva que depende del equipo Basis?

🔗 Más información

Sustainability Control Tower: visibilidad ESG en tiempo real La herramienta permite consolidar métricas ambientales, sociales y de gobernanza en un solo panel conectado a SAP y fuentes externas. El valor es dar a CFOs y responsables de sostenibilidad una visión clara para reportes y decisiones estratégicas. Integrada con BTP, gana aún más potencia: puede aprovechar conectores preconfigurados, flujos de datos en tiempo real y dashboards de analítica avanzada, evitando desarrollos ad-hoc y reduciendo el time-to-value. El reto está en la calidad y consistencia de los datos: una empresa de retail logró integrar emisiones de su cadena logística, pero descubrió que sin estandarizar la captura de datos de proveedores, los reportes perdían comparabilidad.

¿Tu empresa ya mide indicadores ESG de forma integrada con SAP o todavía depende de reportes manuales y dispersos?

🔗 Más información

SAP Build Apps y citizen developers El nuevo release permite que usuarios de negocio creen apps móviles con integración directa a SAP S/4HANA. Esto democratiza la innovación, pero el riesgo es el shadow IT. Un equipo de logística puede crear su propia app de seguimiento, pero ¿qué pasa si no pasa controles de seguridad? El rol de IT pasa de desarrollador a “curador”.

¿En tu empresa los citizen developers son aliados estratégicos o una fuente de dolores de cabeza?

🔗 Más información

Agenda: SAP TechEd 2025 – primeros anuncios SAP adelantó que la próxima edición de TechEd pondrá foco en IA generativa, clean core y analítica en tiempo real. Más allá de los keynotes, lo interesante es ver cómo los anuncios aterrizan en roadmaps concretos. CIOs esperan claridad de inversión, consultores buscan nuevas certificaciones y arquitectos quieren entender las integraciones que vienen.

¿Qué esperás con más interés: casos prácticos de IA, roadmap de S/4HANA o nuevas certificaciones de BTP?

🔗 Más información

SAP BTP ofrece un valor único según el rol que lo mire. Para el CIO significa eficiencia, para el CFO transparencia y control financiero, para el arquitecto la posibilidad de diseñar integraciones más simples, para el Basis la tranquilidad de la estabilidad operativa y para el consultor la oportunidad de acelerar la entrega de valor. Sin embargo, más allá de esas perspectivas, todos enfrentamos la misma tensión: cómo lograr que la innovación se convierta en resultados tangibles sin perder el control en el proceso.

Business User

  • Menschenzentrierter Ansatz zur Identifikation von Business AI Use Cases | 1 h 45 min - Lerne, wie du AI-Use-Case-Workshops durchführst und nimm an unserer Spot-the-Difference-Challenge teil, um Workshop-Materialien zu gewinnen. 

 Administrator

Häufig gestellte Fragen (FAQ)

Was ist SAP Business AI?

SAP Business AI umfasst KI-Funktionen in SAP-Anwendungen und Plattformdiensten: Joule (KI-Copilot), eingebettete KI-Szenarien, Machine Learning auf SAP BTP und Entwicklungstools wie Joule Studio. Diese Technologien automatisieren Prozesse, liefern Datenerkenntnisse und steigern die Produktivität.

Für wen sind SAP AI Trainings geeignet?

  • Entwickler: Für die Erweiterung von KI-Funktionen
Wir bieten Lernpfade für alle Kenntnisstufen.

Gibt es Voraussetzungen für SAP AI Trainings?

  • Einführungskurse: Grundkenntnisse von SAP-Lösungen
  • Entwickler-Kurse: Vorteilhaft sind Programmierkenntnisse wie Python
  • Fortgeschrittene Kurse: Teilweise Erfahrung mit SAP BTP erforderlich

Was kosten SAP AI Trainingsangebote?

  • Kostenlos: Selbstlernkurse, Webinare
  • Einzelkurse: Ab €640/Tag (Instructor-led)
  • SAP Learning Hub: €360 (Partner) und €1.260 (Kunden) jährlich

Wie lange dauert der Abschluss von SAP AI Lernpfaden?

  • Einführung: 10-15 Stunden
  • Rollenbasiert: 20-40 Stunden plus Übungen
  • Zertifizierung: 40-80 Stunden inkl. Prüfung
Die Kurse sind für berufsbegleitendes Lernen konzipiert.

Fachkräfte mit KI-Kompetenzen erzielen 14-28% höhere Gehälter. SAP AI-Expertise ist besonders wertvoll in der digitalen Transformation. Unsere Absolventen berichten von Beförderungen und Führungsrollen in KI-Projekten.

Beginne mit unserem kostenlosen Skills Assessment für persönliche Empfehlungen. Erkunde dann Einführungskurse oder Learning Journeys. Unsere Lernberater helfen dir gerne bei deinem individuellen Entwicklungsplan. Melde Dich gerne bei training.mee@sap.com bei Rückfragen.

entry.title: Session 1 Recap & Highlight - SAP BDC The Future of Intelligent Data Architectures 🚀
entry.content:
Why SAP Invested in BDC 💡

The journey started with SAP’s recognition of a growing "context gap" in enterprise data—which emerges when organizations must stitch together SAP and non-SAP data across disparate platforms (think Databricks, Snowflake, Microsoft Fabric). Without business context, analytics and AI initiatives often struggle to deliver real value. BDC was built to close this gap by harmonizing and managing all enterprise data—structured, semi-structured, SAP, and non-SAP—in a unified, semantically enriched way.

 

What Sets BDC Apart? 🎯

  • Automation First: BDC flips the script on traditional data management, automating data curation and harmonization. Instead of endless upfront effort, customers get ready-to-consume, semantically rich data products—saving time and reducing what SAP calls the “hidden data tax”.
  • Data Product Model: SAP identifies “primary data products” (like finance, supply chain, HR) and brings them directly from SAP applications into BDC, curated and cataloged for instant use. The goal is to reach 500 data products by year-end—covering virtually every major enterprise domain.
  • AI-Ready Fabric: BDC’s lakehouse architecture and built-in “business fabric” layer empower businesses to use advanced analytics, natural language queries, and AI seamlessly. Dual integration and knowledge graph support mean both applications and users can access harmonized, context-rich insights.

 

Interoperability & Ecosystem 🌐

  • BDC Connect: This technology helps integrate BDC with non-SAP systems like Databricks, enabling zero-copy data sharing and harmonized catalogs—perfect for hybrid and multicloud enterprises.
  • Marketplace Vision: SAP is launching a data products marketplace, encouraging partners and customers to publish, consume, and innovate with SAP and non-SAP data. The upcoming announcement at SAP Connect will explain how the ecosystem and intelligent apps can grow—most delivered by partners, not just SAP.

 

Data Democratization: Empowering Every Employee 👥

Pinar described SAP’s internal rollout—“customer zero”—where business users, not just IT, access BDC’s data products and build dashboards in hours. This isn’t just technology; SAP orchestrates enablement cohorts, training citizen analysts to maximize value and foster data-driven decision making at every level.

  • Reusable Data Products: Designed for broad, multi-use case consumption, not one-off analytics. Both IT and business users (citizen analysts) can build, extend, and share data-driven solutions thanks to low-code/no-code tooling.
  • Enablement & Governance: SAP couples technology with strong governance and enablement programs—using Collibra for cataloging, trust-building, and making metadata as easy to navigate as grocery shopping.

 

 

🌍Whether you’re an enterprise architect, citizen analyst, or just curious about the future of business intelligence—SAP Business Data Cloud delivers a new foundation for turning data into real business outcomes, faster and smarter than ever before.

entry.title: Building a CAP service with cds‑mcp and Cline — HANDS‑ON SUPER BASIC GUIDE [ with screenshots ] 🍌
entry.content:
Everything you’re about to read started with this brilliant SAP blog: Boost your CAP development with AI: Introducing the MCP Server for CAP. Think of it as the seed that grew into my little CAP + Cline + banana adventure. 🍌

What you’ll get

  • A friendly walkthrough to spin up a CAP service in VS Code
  • How to wire it to S/4HANA via a BTP Destination for local tests
  • A few real‑world bumps on Windows PATH and global installs
  • A silly “banana mode” at the end to prove handlers actually run 🍌

Prereqs (aka “don’t skip me”)

  • VS Code on Windows
  • Node.js installed and on PATH
  • SAP BTP subaccount with a Destination, e.g. DEVTOBERFEST_DEST to you S4H public cloud [follow my Devtoberfest session for this]
  • Optional: Postman for poking endpoints

Step 1 — Tools on deck

If you try to run cds init and it's not working, follow the next steps.

 

  1. CAP dev kit

npm add -g @sap/cds-dk

If global installs act shy on Windows, add this to PATH then restart VS Code:

  • C:\Users\<YourUser>\AppData\Roaming\npm

 

Step 2 — Cline + CAP MCP server

There are a bunch of AI coding assistants out there — GitHub Copilot, Codeium, Cursor, Tabnine — so why bother with Cline and not Copilot or the others?

Copilot is amazing for inline coding, Cline felt like the right fit for building and testing a whole CAP service with AI in the loop.

  • Install Cline from the VS Marketplace

  • Add the CAP MCP server:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server

  • VS Code settings (snip):

     

Add the MCP Server configuration to your Cline:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": { "command": "cds-mcp", "args": [], "env": {} }
  }
}

Heads‑up: Agents.md wasn’t supported by Cline when I tried it; check again later.

Bonus guardrails, I told Cline:

- Always use cds‑mcp to look up CDS definitions before reading *.cds files.
- Always check CAP docs via cds‑mcp before proposing changes.

If you check on the bottom, you can find the model version:

Cline model picks I tried:

  • anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 — great for agentic coding, supports images/browser/prompt caching.

  • openai/gpt-5 — state-of-the-art for long tasks, supports images/browser, no caching.

  • x-ai/grok-code-fast-1 — free (handy after I burned credits), supports prompt caching but no images/browser.

You can see the differences between all the models, but Grok is free. After using my 10 free prompts, I switched to Grok on my daily to continue working (but not for this blog)

Step 3 — New CAP project

cds init

The cds init command scaffolds a new CAP project.
It creates the basic folder structure (app/, db/, srv/), adds a package.json, and sets up config files so you don’t start from scratch.

In short: it’s the “hello world” starter for CAP — without it, you’d have to wire everything by hand.

Step 4 — Bring in Business Partner and scaffold

After importing the EDMX file [check my video on the Devtoberfest], let's try a prompt. We want to apply this prompt to Cline:

Extend API_BUSINESS_PARTNER.

Create service.cds and service.js.

Expose only BusinessPartner with READ and CREATE. If the name contains “banana”, throw an error.

Result: service.cds and service.js created. MCP caching made later calls cheaper. Nice.

For this blog, I bought 2$ of credit just for testing (I already used all the free ones). Let’s see how much it will be used.

 
 

The creation seems to be working fine, and we used 82.6k credits, which is close to $1. Let’s continue the process and create the service.cds by clicking save.

The service.js file was created correctly. We also used fewer tokens because we cached the query before sending it to the MCP server.

The file also seems fine. I would not expect anything else after this, but Cline is asking me that :

Now let me check if there's a package.json file to understand the project setup and then test the implementation. and it want to read the package.json file.

I want to be more specific in this case. I have a destination defined in my btp with already access to my S4HC and exposed the business partner scenario. I would like to test locally by using this destination and my new project. Let’s then correct and add new information with my prompt.

I would like you check the package.json and prepare the project for deploy and test locally. I have a BTP destination ready and connected with name DEVTOBERFEST_DEST

 

As a money saver, I get a little annoyed paying 3 cents to ask me to run npm install, even though I know I need to do it always.
It’s fine for testing and learning purposes lol.

And another 6 cents to check and suggested me npm start. But let’s imagine we are new in this CAP world and we follow blindly Cline and the MCP.

Step 5 — Prep for local testing with a Destination

Have a BTP Destination named DEVTOBERFEST_DEST that points to the S/4HANA Business Partner API.

After this point, I decided to add my MTA file and the destination configuration (to connect to the system) by myself. Without using any AI tool

cds add mta;
cds add xsuaa,destination,connectivity;

Step 6 — Build, deploy, and test


Install all the package dependencies with

npm i

I decided to build and deploy by using Cline.
Something I notice differently in my usual process is the new terminal type Cline on the right.

Everything went fine, and from my postman, I can see the call


This one was the first significant milestone. I think the most challenging part was to make VSCode (for me, who I am a Business Application Code user). Let's try something more fun.

Step 7 — Banana mode (purely for fun)

I asked (Because why not?):

When filtering by BusinessPartnerFullName for "Sebastiano Marchesini", make every field say "banana". 

This request took the MCP multiple steps and ended with $0.89 in expenses.

Not bad for banana mode, but it didn’t fully understand my request. The code set everything to ‘banana’ whenever it found one in the result.

This still teaches a big truth about our development: we cannot leave everything to the AI, but we need to take care of our code and pay attention to what we produce. 
Now....

entry.title: Enabling Agent Interoperability: A Practical Path from API to MCP Server
entry.content:
The future of enterprise AI will be driven by the deep and seamless integration of LLMs into existing enterprise products and workflows. To stay competitive, companies must make their vast landscape of existing capabilities directly accessible and usable by AI, empowering a new generation of intelligent ecosystems. This requires a clear strategy for enabling agent interoperability.

In this article, we will establish that the journey to agent interoperability begins with a foundational pillar: enabling agents to reliably connect with tools (Agent-to-Tool). We'll start by defining the foundational challenge that prevents agents and tools from communicating effectively. We will then introduce the Model Context Protocol (MCP) as a standardized solution and walk through a step-by-step tutorial on how to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server using a cloud-native gateway.

 

What is Agent Interoperability and Why Does It Matter?

Agent Interoperability is a comprehensive framework for a complete AI ecosystem, which relies on two fundamental pillars: Agent-to-Agent (A2A) interaction and Agent-to-Tool (A2T) interaction.

While A2A interaction—how agents collaborate and delegate tasks—represents a sophisticated, multi-agent system's goal, A2T interaction is the foundational prerequisite. The ability of agents to collaborate is contingent upon their individual capacity to connect to tools.

Therefore, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability. While not an Agent-to-Agent protocol itself, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability: how to let any agent discover and use any external capability in a standardized way.

 

Foundational Challenge: Connecting Agents to Enterprise Tools

In an enterprise environment like SAP, this challenge presents distinct engineering considerations on both sides of the connection:

  • On the agent side: The challenge is building agents with the autonomy to dynamically discover and utilize a diverse set of capabilities, moving beyond static tool integrations.
  • On the capability side: The engineering task is to adapt SAP's vast landscape of powerful APIs for a new type of consumer: the autonomous AI agent. The goal is to create AI-consumable interfaces for these existing capabilities, which involves adding the necessary semantic context and standardized formats that agents require for dynamic interaction.

This difference in design paradigms creates a natural "Interoperability Gap”. Bridging this gap requires a foundational layer for communication: a standardized protocol that enables dynamic discovery and standardized interaction between agents and established enterprise APIs.

 

The Solution: MCP as a Standardized Protocol Bridge

So, how do we bridge this "Interoperability Gap"? The solution lies in a shared standard—a common language that both agents and tools can speak. This is where the Model Context Protocol (MCP)  comes in.

MCP is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models (LLMs). MCP provides a standardized way to connect AI models to different data sources and tools.

We use MCP to build agents and complex workflows on top of LLMs. The key participants in the MCP architecture are:

  • MCP Host: The AI application that coordinates and manages one or multiple MCP clients
  • MCP Client: A component that maintains a connection to an MCP server and obtains context from an MCP server for the MCP host to use
  • MCP Server: A program that provides context to MCP clients

As for enterprise like SAP, the best practice will be:

However, a protocol is only useful if capabilities adopt it. The enterprise landscape is filled with valuable, pre-existing REST APIs that were not built for this new paradigm. Therefore, a critical first step toward achieving agent interoperability is to bridge these legacy APIs to the MCP standard.

The act of transforming a standard API into a discoverable MCP Server is the foundational process for unlocking existing enterprise value for AI agents. 

 

MCP Adoption Strategy in Enterprise Ecosystems

When adopting a new standard like MCP within a large enterprise ecosystem like SAP, there are typically two primary strategic paths to consider for implementation:

1. The Standard Path: Platform-Managed Solutions

For most common use cases, the standard approach is to leverage platform-integrated, centrally managed solutions. This path involves using automated services, often provided by the enterprise platform (e.g., SAP BTP), to convert existing APIs into standardized tools. By using unified method for transformation, this approach ensures consistency and manageability across the entire ecosystem.

2. The Flexible Path: Custom or "Native" Implementations

For scenario demanding greater flexibility or more complex business logic, a more custom approach is required. This involves building what can be considered "native" MCP servers. This approach allows teams to build custom implementations using a variety of technologies, such as open-source libraries or different programming languages, giving them full control over the implementation.

This Guide's Focus: A Hands-on Example of the Flexible Path

In the following guide, we will focus on the flexible, native server approach.  We will demonstrate a powerful and practical pattern for this by using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to wrap an existing API. This method is ideal for teams who require full control over the transformation logic and deployment environment, providing a valuable, hands-on example of building a native-style MCP server.

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Transforming API into MCP Server

To see how this concept works in the real world, let's take a standard REST API and use a gateway to transform it into a fully-compliant MCP server.

Our Goal: Wrap a simple HTTP API as an MCP Server and invoke it from an agent.

Our Tools:

  • A Simple API: A REST API that returns real-time currency exchange data.
  • The Gateway: Higress, an open-source, cloud-native gateway with a powerful plugin architecture.
  • The Standard: The Model Context Protocol (MCP), which we'll implement using the Higress MCP Plugin.
  • The Environment: A Kubernetes environment.

 

A Modern Transport Protocol: Streamable HTTP

Before we begin, it's important to understand transport mechanisms for client-server communication we'll be using. This guide utilizes a modern and powerful approach defined by the MCP standard: Streamable HTTP.

We chose this approach for several key advantages that make it superior for modern AI systems:

  • Simplified Architecture: In the Streamable HTTP transport, the server operates as an independent process that can handle multiple client connections. Because the session context is maintained within this single, stateful connection, the need for an external session manager like Redis is often eliminated.
  • Bidirectional and Flexible Communication: The protocol handles simple request-response patterns efficiently but also enables true bidirectional communication. Server can optionally make use of Server-Sent Events (SSE) to stream multiple server messages. This permits basic MCP servers, as well as more feature-rich servers supporting streaming and server-to-client notifications and requests.

 

Step 1: The Starting Point - A Simple REST API

As the requirement of Streamable HTTP, The server MUST provide a single HTTP endpoint path (hereafter referred to as the MCP endpoint) that supports both POST and GET methods.

To demonstrate the transformation process, this guide will use the ExchangeRate-API, a professional service that provides real-time currency exchange data. We'll use its lasted endpoint, which returns up-to-date global rates based on the US Dollar.

  • API Endpoint: https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD

A successful request to this endpoint returns a JSON object with a structure similar to this, containing metadata and a nested rates object:

{
  "result": "success",
  "time_last_update_utc": "Mon, 15 Sep 2025 00:02:31 +0000",
  "base_code": "USD",
  "rates": {
    "USD": 1,
    "EUR": 0.925,
    "GBP": 0.789,
    ...
  }
}

This represents a typical "legacy" capability—useful, but not inherently agent-friendly. 

 

Step 2: Preparing the Gateway with Higress

Instead of modifying the API's code, we'll use a gateway to act as a transformation layer. Higress is an ideal choice because its plugin architecture is designed to extend gateway capabilities, including native support for AI scenarios through protocols like MCP.

2.1 Higress Deployment

First, install Higress into your cluster environment (To simplify, we use k3s as an example).

Check your console's node port:

kubectl get svc higress-console -n higress-system

Once the installation succeeds, you can access the Higress Console in browser by http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>.  

 

2.2 Config MCP Server

Once deployed, we need to enable the MCP Server functionality globally by editing the higress-config ConfigMap.

kubectl edit configmap higress-config -n higress-system

In the ConfigMap data, we'll add the MCP Server configuration. 

apiVersion: v1
data:
  higress: |-
    mcpServer:
      sse_path_suffix: /sse  # Suffix for the Server-Sent Events connection path
      enable: true           # Enable the MCP Server
      servers: []
  downstream:
    # ... (rest of the config)

 

Step 3: Transforming the API with the MCP Plugin

3.1 Add a Service Source

In the Higress Console, navigate to Service Source page http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>/service-source  and add a new source pointing to our API's address (https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD).

 

3.2 Create a Route

Next, go to the Route page and create a new route.

  • Click "Route Config" on the left sidebar
  • Click "Create Route" button
  • Fill in the form with the following details:
    • Route Name: exchange-rate-route
    • Path: Select Exact and enter /exchange-rates
    • Target Service: Select the service source you just created

This will create a route that matches the path /exchange-rates and forwards requests to the service source you created. Now you can see the new route in the list.

At this point, Higress will simply proxy requests from /exchange-rates to our API.

 

3. Configure the MCP Server Plugin

Click the Strategy link on your new route and find the MCP Server plugin.

 

After enabling the plugin, click "Configure" and switch to the YAML view. This is where we define the metadata that makes our API discoverable and understandable to agents.

 

Paste the following configuration:

server:
  name: "exchange-rate-server"
tools:
  - name: "get-latest-usd-rates"
    description: "Fetches the latest currency exchange rates based on the US Dollar."
    requestTemplate:
      method: "GET"
      url: "https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD"
    responseTemplate:
      body: |-
        **Latest Exchange Rates (Base: {{.base_code}})**
        *Updated at: {{.time_last_update_utc}}*
        
        - **Euro (EUR):** {{.rates.EUR}}
        - **Japanese Yen (JPY):** {{.rates.JPY}}
        - **British Pound (GBP):** {{.rates.GBP}}
        - **Chinese Yuan (CNY):** {{.rates.CNY}}

Let's break this down:

  • server.name: A human-readable name for our new MCP server.
  • tools: A list of capabilities this server provides.
  • name & description: The crucial metadata for agent to intelligently discover and select this tool when a user asks about exchange rates.
  • requestTemplate & responseTemplate: These define how Higress calls the backend API and formats the response. Here, the requestTemplate specifies a simple GET request, and the responseTemplate transforms the JSON output into a clean, agent-friendly format.

Save the plugin configuration. Our standard REST API is now exposed as a fully functional and discoverable MCP Server, ready for any compliant AI agent to use.

 

Step 4: Connecting and Invoking from an Agent with Streamable HTTP

Now, any MCP-compliant agent or client can connect to our gateway and use this new tool. To test our new MCP server, we can use any compliant MCP Host app, such as Cline, Cursor, Trae, etc.

For this guide, we'll use Cline as example. It's an autonomous coding agent that can be installed as a VS Code extension. Configure Cline with the following setting to establish a connection to our new server:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "exchange-rate-server": {
      "url": "http://<your-cluster-external-ip>/exchange-rates",
      "type": "streamableHttp"
    }
  }
}

Now you can test the server in Cline:

 

Wrapping Up

In this post, we've navigated a practical path toward the broader vision of agent interoperability. We established that the most critical first step is solving the Agent-to-Tool (A2T) challenge: making existing enterprise APIs discoverable and usable by AI agents. We then demonstrated a powerful pattern to achieve this, using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server.

The most powerful takeaway is demonstrating a flexible path to a native server: You've learned how a gateway-centric pattern can be used to build a "native" MCP server, offering full control to teams that require flexibility and customization in their MCP adoption strategy. It means existing, valuable enterprise services can be rapidly integrated into the agent ecosystem, making them dynamically discoverable and usable by any MCP-compliant agent.

Solving the Agent-to-Tool problem building the foundation for agent interoperability. With a robust A2T layer in place, the path is cleared for more advanced Agent-to-Agent collaboration, paves the way for a future where countless enterprise services can be seamlessly integrated with agent ecosystem.

entry.title: Building Custom LLM Agent in Databricks: An Example Generating AI Responses from Customer Review
entry.content:
Hi Everyone!
As we know that Large Language Models (LLMs) are changing how businesses work with data and with Agent Bricks in Databricks, we can build smart agents that understand our specific business needs and are part of our data workflows. Using Generative AI, these agents can create insights, answer questions, and suggest actions, turning raw data into useful, actionable information.

Now let's deep dive into what Agent Bricks is and see how it can be put to work.

1. What is Agent Bricks?
Agent Bricks provides a simple way to build and optimize domain-specific, high-quality AI agent systems, allowing us to package LLM-based agents as reusable building blocks for common AI applications. It leverages Databricks Mosaic AI, enabling us to quickly and easily deploy comprehensive AI agent systems tailored to our unique data.
Source:
Databricks - Agent Bricks

2. Using Agent Bricks
Let us start by creating a custom LLM agent
Step 1: Identify use case

  • Define the specific purpose of your agent
  • Example: Generate AI-driven responses based on customer reviews
  • Specify the input data (e.g., customer reviews) and expected output (e.g., responses to reviews)

Lets decide our use case of "Generating AI responses from customer reviews"

Step 2: Create a labeled dataset
For our use case, we need a table with customer name and order review. As the agent accepts only one input, we have combined customer name and order review in one column called "customer_review"

Step 3: Creating a custom LLM model 
We will click on Agents tab on the left and then select Build under custom LLM model

After that in the next screen, we will enter an agent name and provide the instruction set in "Describe your task" section

The instruction set used is provided below:

You are a customer support assistant writing a response to a customer review. You are given a text where the customer name and their review are concatenated in one column.
The format is always:
<Customer Name>|<Customer Review>

    "Your task:
    1. Split the text into two parts: "customer name" and "review"
    2. Begin the response by greeting the customer using their name (e.g., 'Dear John,').
    2. Write a warm, professional and empathetic response acknowledging the customer's concern in English.
    3. Acknowledge the customer’s frustration and **apologize sincerely**.
    4. **Reassure the customer** that their concern is being taken seriously and that the issue will be reviewed to prevent recurrence.
    5. Keep the tone friendly, concise, and polite.
    6. If no follow-up reason is provided or the review is positive, write a kind Thank-you message instead.
    7. Keep the response under 100 words.

    Your response must show **genuine concern and accountability**. Always respond in fluent English.
    In the output update only response and nothing else")

After that we select the labeled dataset option and provide table name, input column and output column as shown below, and then click on Create Agent. If we want we can also use unstructured data like PDFs for our analysis by selecting unlabeled dataset.

Step 4: Train the Agent
In the next screen, we will review the guidelines created based on the instruction set and additionally more guidelines can be added. We then review the response provided by the agent to improve quality of the agent. This allows the agent to learn patterns from examples while following our custom guidelines.

We can also go to Quality Report tab to analyze the checks we have done and how is the agent performing as per our requirement

Step 5: Optimizing the agent
We can optimize the agent to be more cost effective thus saving us costs. Click on Optimize tab and select Start Optimization.

Once optimizations is complete, we can compare the quality of new agent based on our baseline agent and if it meets our requirement, we can deploy the optimized agent.

Step 6: Using the agent
We can try using the Agent by clicking on Use button as highlighted below. We can use the Agent using SQL, create an ETL Pipeline or use the agent in AI Playground.

Let's use the SQL option for our use case. Below query is generated in a new SQL editor using the custom endpoint created for our agent as highlighted below and uses the table that it is built on for testing

3. Using Agent Bricks in SQL
Once the agent is ready, we can use it via SQL in multiple ways.
First, let's create a SQL function using the custom end point of the agent and the SQL AI function "ai_query". This function will accept customer review as an input and generate AI response for each customer review.


Now lets create a table using the custom endpoint of the agent so that we can generate AI responses for all the customer reviews and save it in a table.

4. Benefits of using Agent Bricks:

  • Consistency & Reliability - Agent Bricks ensures that responses follow the rules every time. For example, if our guideline says “always include the customer’s name in the response,” the agent enforces it.
  • Reusability Across Teams -  Once created, an Agent can be reused by different teams or workflows without rebuilding  the prompt. This reduces duplication and speeds up agent adoption across the organization.
  • Quality Control - Agent can be reviewed, fine-tuned, and evaluated systematically for controlling the desired output.
  • Cost Optimization - Agent can be optimized to reduce costs and it can also save costs by using batch processing.

5. Alternative to Agent Bricks
We can alternatively create a custom SQL AI function using an LLM like LlaMA model and AI_QUERY function to achieve the same output. For example, we can write a SQL function that takes the customer name and review text as input and returns an AI-generated response.

We can then use the created function to generate the customer response

This function works fine but it has some drawbacks:

  • No Quality Testing - The output cannot be systematically tested or reviewed for quality as we cannot provide feedback to the SQL AI function.
  • Inconsistent Results - It is harder to ensure the responses follow consistent rules across large datasets.
  • Higher Cost Risk - It can have higher cost risk as each SQL query call processes data row by row.

5. Integration with SAP BDC
Currently, Agents is still in Preview in Databricks and is not available in SAP Databricks.
We hope that it becomes GA and be made available in SAP Databricks also.

As an alternate, for now, we can regenerate customer response table generated above using SQL function instead of agent and then we can share this table back to BDC using the SAP BDC connector.
We can then use this table as a data product for our case in our dashboards or reports.
Source:
SAP - Sharing Data Products from SAP Databricks to SAP Business Data Cloud 
Databricks -  Share data between SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and Databricks


We can also watch the below video shared by Arijit Banerjee that was presented by him in this year's Databricks Tech Summit:

This video clearly explains how we can share data products from SAP BDC to SAP Databricks and then make changes in Databricks and share the new tables back to SAP BDC.

Conclusion:
Agent Bricks in Databricks allows businesses to:

  • Customize AI agents with labeled or unlabeled datasets and clear instructions
  • Review and refine outputs for reliability
  • Deploy agents directly in SQL for scalable automation
  • Reduce costs by optimizing the agent

By combining data and AI, Agent Bricks helps us to unlock a new level of automation and personalization for modern businesses.

entry.title: Unleashing Creativity with Cloud-Based AI Apps: 2025 Premium Hub CoE High School Summer Orientation
entry.content:
This summer, a group of bright high school students embarked on an exciting journey at SAP's week-long STEM orientation program. This program focused on harnessing the power of cloud-based AI apps using the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), providing students with practical, hands-on learning experiences using low-code/no-code tools.

 

 

Building the Foundation with SAP Build Apps:

The week kicked off with students getting an introduction into SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and Artificial Intelligence at SAP. A key component of the learning experience was SAP Build Apps, a powerful tool within SAP BTP that enabled students to design and develop applications using a low-code/no-code approach. This tool simplified the app creation process, allowing students to focus on functionality and creativity rather than complex coding.

The primary task was to create a barcode scanner application using SAP Build Apps. This app scanned barcodes and retrieved detailed information about food items from the Open Food Facts API, a free and open database of food product information. This integration taught students how to connect their applications to external data sources, demonstrating the potential of combining SAP BTP with other digital resources.

Adding a Generative AI Twist:

The real magic happened when students were introduced to Google Gemini, allowing them to enhance their applications with Generative AI capabilities. By integrating AI into their apps, students were able to analyze the health aspects of food ingredients, transforming simple barcode scanners into intelligent, interactive applications. This exercise encouraged students to think critically about how AI can enhance user experiences and provide valuable insights.

Showcasing Innovation:

As the week progressed, students eagerly worked on their projects, each bringing their own flair to the task. They showcased the culmination of their hard work in a demo session held on Friday, presenting their enhanced applications. It was inspiring to see how each participant leveraged the tools and guidance provided to create something truly remarkable.

Reflecting on the Experience:

The orientation week was not just about building apps; it was about fostering a spirit of innovation and collaboration. The students left with more than just technical skills; they gained confidence and a deeper understanding of how technology can be used to solve real-world problems.

The feedback from participants has been overwhelmingly positive, with many expressing how the program has sparked a new interest in technology and AI.

Here's what one of our students had to say about their unforgettable experience:

“Thank you so much for organizing such a great practicum experience at SAP. I really enjoyed the week and learned a lot, especially”during the project work and all the tours. Getting to explore the SAP Build platform and contribute to the barcode scanner project was a really cool experience, and it helped me understand how tech is used in the real world.

I also really appreciated how friendly and supportive everyone was throughout the week. The tours of the MCC and Smart Factory, as well as the leadership talk on the last day, were really inspiring and gave me a better idea of the kinds of roles I might want to explore in the future.

Thanks again for the opportunity, and I’m really grateful for the experience!”- Mehul Vijayvergiya

 

Looking Forward:

This orientation was a testament to the power of education and technology in shaping the minds of tomorrow's innovators. As we continue to provide these opportunities, we are excited to see how these young minds will contribute to the ever-evolving tech landscape.

entry.title: Hello Python: My First Script in SAP BAS Connecting to HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Credit: @Vitaliy-R Your startup blogs kindled my interest to explore working with Python in SAP ecosystem. Python in BAS and Jupyter in BAS 

When I first started exploring SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I was curious about how Python could fit into the SAP landscape. I’ve mostly associated BAS with HANA artefacts(SQLScript, hdbcalculationview, hdbreptask etc.) and CAP artefacts, so writing a Python script inside BAS felt like venturing into new territory. My goal was simple: write a basic script and connect it to SAP HANA Cloud. What I discovered along the way is that Python not only works smoothly in BAS but also makes it easy to interact with HANA Cloud, opening up opportunities for data exploration, automation, and integration in a way that feels both modern and approachable.

Before jumping into the Python script, I had to get my environment ready in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). Here’s what I set up:

A BAS dev space with a full-stack cloud application space since it supports multiple runtimes, including Python. I had a space with HANA Native Application type. Since the Python tools extension is not added by default, I edited the space to select the Python tools in the additional extension options. 

HANA Dev Space Python extension

 Note: For initial steps to check the Python version, Jupyter notebook and set ups refer to the blogs listed at the start. 

Use Case: I attempted to achieve the following: 

  • Establish a connection to HANA Cloud
  • Execute an SQL query on a table/view 
  • Display the results

In the BAS, I created a project from Template: SAP HANA Database Project

 

Next step: Create a notebook file. 

My guide to connect to HANA Cloud: Connect to HANA Cloud 

When I first tried importing hdbcli into my Jupyter Notebook within BAS, I ran into the same ModuleNotFoundError. Even though I had already installed hdbcli In the terminal, the notebook kernel wasn’t recognizing it. On some search and prompting with GPT( 😁), I understood that it's a common issue because Jupyter can run in a different Python environment than the terminal. The fix was simple: I ran

import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install hdbcli

directly in a notebook cell. This ensures that the HANA client is installed in the same environment as the notebook kernel. After this step, I could successfully import dbapi and connect to HANA Cloud without any errors. It was a small but important lesson about Python environments in BAS, especially when using Jupyter.

With the hdbcli package installed and working in my Jupyter Notebook, I was ready to write my first Python script to connect to SAP HANA Cloud.

In the next cell, I imported hdbcli in this notebook. 

import hdbcli
print(hdbcli.__file__)

 

 The next step was to gain access to the dbapi interface, which allows you to establish connections, execute SQL queries, and fetch results from your HANA Cloud instance. This simple import is the gateway to working with HANA directly from Python.

from hdbcli import dbapi

The next step is to establish a connection to your HANA Cloud instance. This requires specifying the host, port, username, and password.

 After connecting, you can create a cursor object to execute SQL statements. An SQL statement, preferably a Select Query to test the retrieval of data from HANA Cloud. In my case, I used a Select with count on the number of records in a view. Once the variables were ready, execute the connection cursor object.

Note: in the SQL variable, use single quotes and a semicolon at the end of the query. (beginner tip 🙂 )

Now is the time to test the data retrieval from the script and compare it with the Database Explorer.

Drum roll....🥁

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Hurray 🎉

Completing my first Python script in SAP Business Application Studio and connecting it to HANA Cloud was an exciting milestone. From the initial curiosity to the small hurdles like installing hdbcli in the notebook and finally seeing my script return results, every step felt like a mini victory.

That simple output from HANA Cloud made all the effort worthwhile and gave me a real sense of accomplishment.

This experience has sparked my curiosity to explore more complex queries, data analysis, and automation using Python in SAP.

I hope my journey inspires others to take that first step and discover how fun and powerful working with Python and HANA Cloud can be.

Chao.

entry.title: Strengthening Fairness and Consistency in AI-Enabled Features
entry.content:
Credits: Yasmin Dwiputri & Data Hazards Project / https://betterimagesofai.org / https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

The information provided in this blog post is for general informational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. Readers should consult with qualified legal professionals regarding any specific questions or concerns related to regulatory compliance or other obligations.

At SAP, we’re continually working to ensure that our AI-enabled features perform reliably and responsibly across diverse use cases.

Since the introduction of our SAP Global AI Ethics Policy and the launch of our AI Ethics Assessment process in 2022, we’ve implemented evaluation practices that help identify and address unintended outcomes in development.

To support this effort, we partnered with SAP SuccessFactors to explore practical ways of evaluating AI-enabled features. This collaboration led to the creation of internal resources to help guide teams through these evaluations.

Below, you’ll find answers to some frequently asked questions from our teams working with these evaluation practices.

What are inconsistent outcomes in AI systems and how do they relate to fairness or bias?Inconsistent outcomes in AI systems – often referred to as bias – refer to measurable differences in how individuals or groups are treated. These differences can arise from data or design choices that unintentionally influence model behavior. For example, if an AI system produces different results based on certain characteristics – such as age, gender, or other demographic factors – it may be treating people unfairly. When these patterns persist and lead to unequal performance or decision-making, they raise concerns about fairness. Ensuring that AI systems deliver fair and consistent outcomes across diverse user groups is key to building trust and avoiding unintended harm.
What are ‘proxy variables’ in AI evaluations? When evaluating AI systems for fairness and consistent outcomes, it’s important to consider how certain personal attributes can appear in data either directly or indirectly: 
  • Direct descriptors are data points that explicitly identify a personal attribute, e.g., a date of birth revealing the age of a person. 
  • Indirect descriptors or proxy variables are data points that may not directly identify a personal attribute but that are strongly correlated with it. For example, a name may suggest national origin; or a combination of gender and age may imply pregnancy likelihood.

Fairness is a widely recognized principle in Data Protection and Privacy (DPP) frameworks. To uphold fairness in AI systems, it’s essential to test AI systems for both types of variables. This helps ensure that AI systems behave consistently across different user groups.

Which type of testing is appropriate for identifying inconsistent outcomes in an AI system?The types of testing needed to evaluate inconsistent outcomes depends on the type of AI that is being leveraged and its intended use case. 

A key consideration is whether your team is developing their own Narrow AI (i.e., non-Generative-AI) model or whether they leverage a 3rd party foundation model such as large language models (LLMs). When working with 3rd party LLMs, it may be appropriate to treat them as black boxes for testing purposes since the underlying data and model properties (architecture, training process, objective function, etc.) are often not accessible. In these cases, testing can focus on evaluating outputs across different scenarios and user groups to detect potential inconsistencies. In contrast, when it comes to Narrow AI systems developed in-house, training data and model design choices can be reviewed to identify patterns that may lead to inconsistent outcomes. This allows for more targeted evaluations, such as inspecting data distributions and identifying systemic performance disparities across demographic groups.

How can Narrow AI models be tested for consistent outcomes?When evaluating AI systems for consistent outcomes, it's helpful to consider three distinct approaches:
  • Individual consistency: Similar individuals should receive similar results.
  • Group outcome consistency: Outcome distribution should be balanced across demographic groups.
  • Group performance consistency: Prediction quality (e.g., error rates) should be comparable across groups.

To understand whether differences in AI results are meaningful, statistical significance tests can be conducted. These tests validate whether any observed inconsistencies are likely real or random.

Together, these tests help ensure AI systems deliver consistent and reliable performance.

How many test cases are needed to evaluate an AI system for fairness and consistency?The number of test cases depends on the specific use case, the types of outcome variability, and the evaluation method. As a general guideline, test datasets should be balanced and reflect the diversity found in real-world data. For instance, when evaluating how an AI system responds to names associated with different genders, include a balanced and varied set of name types to ensure reliable coverage. In some cases, sample size testing can help determine whether a dataset is large enough to detect meaningful differences in system behavior across user groups. The goal is to build confidence that the AI performs consistently and predictably across varied scenarios.

entry.title: New Critical Content Now Live in the SAP Support Portal: Empowering You with Faster, Smarter Support
entry.content:
We’re excited to introduce Critical Content, now available in the Support by Product Pages in the SAP Support Portal, bringing you faster access to the most essential resources for your product.

What Is Critical Content?

Critical Content includes expert-recommended articles and solutions that address the most severe issues—those that could lead to major business disruptions if not addressed in time. These resources are now surfaced directly on your product’s support page, making it easier than ever to stay informed and take action.

You may already be familiar with Hot Content, which highlights major issues that could impact a large number of customers and typically result in support requests if no guidance is provided. Trending Content shows you what other customers are viewing most today. These are the most-accessed solutions across the platform—real-time insights into what’s relevant and helpful right now.

Critical Content, on the other hand, focuses on high-impact issues specific to your product—those that could cause serious business consequences if overlooked. It’s about proactive support, helping you resolve problems before they escalate.
